summary: This is a DOJ OIG interview transcript of a BOP employee (Captain) who was the Captain at MCC New York during Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death. The interview focuses on security protocols, staffing, cellmate assignments, rounds, counts, and the circumstances leading to Epstein's death on August 10, 2019. The witness discusses failures in communication, falsified counts, missing inmate files, and his belief that Epstein died by suicide.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: High-profile inmate found dead in his cell at MCC New York on August 10, 2019. The interview discusses his behavior, housing, and the circumstances of his death.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's former cellmate, a former police officer convicted of murder. Epstein accused him of trying to kill him in July 2019, but the claim was deemed not credible.

persons.name: Efrain Reyes
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate selected through a vetting process. He was released from court on August 9, 2019, leaving Epstein without a cellmate, which was not properly communicated.

persons.name: Joaquin Guzman
persons.context: Notorious drug kingpin housed in the Ten South unit at MCC, mentioned as an example of a high-security inmate.

persons.name: Tova Noel
persons.context: Officer assigned to the SHU on the morning watch shift when Epstein was found dead. Admitted to not conducting rounds and counts.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: Officer working overtime in the SHU on the morning watch shift when Epstein was found. Admitted to not conducting rounds and entered Epstein's cell without supervision.

persons.name: Brianna Rose Burton
persons.context: Transcriber certified the accuracy of the transcript.

events.title: Epstein found unresponsive with homemade fabric
events.description: Epstein was found unresponsive on the floor of his cell with a homemade piece of fabric on his chest. His cellmate Tartaglione alerted staff. Epstein claimed Tartaglione tried to kill him, but the investigation found the claim not credible.

events.title: Efrain Reyes released from court
events.description: Inmate Efrain Reyes, Epstein's cellmate, was released from court and did not return to MCC, leaving Epstein without a cellmate. This was not properly communicated to supervising staff.

events.title: Epstein found dead
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York in the early morning hours. He was pronounced dead. Officers Noel and Thomas admitted to not conducting rounds and counts that night.

events.title: OIG Interview of BOP Captain
events.description: DOJ OIG conducts a voluntary sworn interview with the BOP Captain who was in charge of security at MCC during Epstein's incarceration, as part of the investigation into Epstein's death.

locations: MCC New York (Metropolitan Correctional Center), 150 Park Row, New York, NY
West Side Administrative Building, FCI Fort Dix
Ten South unit (Special Management Unit) at MCC
keyFacts: Epstein was not in his assigned cell for six days prior to his death; inmates were moved but Sentry paperwork was not updated.
Epstein's SHU inmate file was missing key documents (intake screenings, 292s, psychology notes) when secured after his death, suggesting possible removal.
The 4:00 p.m., 10:00 p.m., 12:00 a.m., 3:00 a.m., and 5:00 a.m. counts on August 9-10, 2019, were not conducted, and count slips were falsified.
Officers Tova Noel and Michael Thomas admitted to not conducting rounds and counts on the morning of Epstein's death, and camera footage showed them sleeping.
The witness believes Epstein died by suicide and does not believe any staff harmed him, but cites systemic failures in communication, supervision, and protocol adherence.
